utterances: He was a perennial NBA All-Star and Olympic gold medalist, but in recent years, Alonzo Mourning has been the king of the comeback.
Zo became the second player in the history of the league to return to the court after a kidney transplant.
His passion for the game and desire for a championship ring returned him to the Miami Heat this season, where he also made news off the court.
Zo donated his entire Heat salary to help young people in south Florida.
His tradition of giving is as long as his tenure in the NBA.
Every year he hosts Zo's Summer Groove, a charity event to raise money for the education and development for at-risk children.
Joining us now to talk about the event is the man himself, Alonzo Mourning.
Zo, what's happening, man?
Not much, man.
How you doing?
I'm good, man.
OK.
Once again, a hot time in good old Miami, F-L-A.
Tell us a little bit about what you got planned down there.

This year Tyson and Pepsi have stepped up to the plate, and they're our title sponsors this year, and we've had a tremendous amount of success, you know, due to the fact that the city has embraced it, and the entertainers and actors have come down and supported the event, and has made the process so much easier to support the organizations that help our young people in south Florida.
You've been dedicated to helping young people for as long as I've known you.
Yeah.

I'm curious what it is about you--you know, skeptics might say, `Well, he, you know, walked close to death and now he understands,' but you knew this before you had any issues with your kidney or any health problems.
So talk to me about the makeup of you and why you do this.
Well, I don't listen to skeptics no more, and this--my faith is extremely strong, you know?
And God is the only guiding light that I have in my life, you know.
And there's a reason why he's put me in the situations, you know.
There's just so many positive things having merged out of me going through transplantation and chronic kidney disorder.
I've been able to reach out to so many other people and inspire them through my efforts.

I have utilized my strengths and looked back on the journey I've had to go through as a child and utilized that as a strength of mine in knowing that, `Hey, there are a lot of other people, young people out there, who have the ability; they just don't have the resources.
You know?
So I try to go out--I've created this foundation to help create a positive atmosphere so people could come out, enjoy themselves with events in giving.

And, Zo, we shouldn't minimize the importance of--particularly for African-American youth--the idea of these kids being able to touch, feel, talk to celebrities, people that they see as successful, really can go a long way in assisting them to know that it can happen to them.
Well, it's a matter of just feeding them the right information, man, you know?
Kids are like sponges.
It's up to us as adults to be a little bit more responsible instead of pointing the finger at statistics and kids dropping out of school, do something about it.
I remember sitting with you in the barbershop--is where we were when you were here in New Jersey playing for the Nets and it was...
Right.
...right as you started your comeback and I remember talking to you about how positive you seemed to be.
Have you always been that way?
(Singing) Could you be one?
Johnny and the sprites.
(Singing) Johnny and the sprites.

John Tartaglia is also the executive producer of ""Johnny and the Sprites,"" which combines live actors with puppets to tell stories about tolerance and understanding — in this case, between humans and woodland sprites.
He says he and his collaborators wanted to use theater songwriters on his show from the start.
We were bemoaning the fact that children's music is so dumb down nowadays.
And that - children are treated as these, you know, robots, that they only like this and they only will get this.
And I think that all the lyricists and composers and myself got really excited about the idea of bringing this music to kids.
Tartaglia's got some top-shelf talent working on the program, including none other than Stephen Schwartz, whose credits include the mega-hit musicals ""Wicked"", ""Pippin"" and ""Godspell.
I had been hearing from John about ""Johnny and The Sprites"" when it was just a gleam in his eye.
And, you know, he asked me if I would do things for it and, partly because John is a friend of mine, frankly, but partly because the project sounded intriguing, you know, I said I would.
And then wound up doing the theme song.
(Soundbite of ""Johnny and the Sprites"" Theme Song)
(Singing) That's our song now.
Johnny and the Sprites.
(Singing) Johnny and the Sprites.
Johnny and the Sprites"" on the Disney Channel, is one of two New York-based cable television shows employing Broadway talent.
The other is Nick Jr.'s animated series the ""Wonder Pets."" That show is about adorable classroom pets who form a team of secret superheroes to rescue baby animals in trouble.
Josh Selig is the producer.
We've looked for great composers, who also have a sense of humor and who can really do more than write a song, but can really tell a story with music.
And we've been thrilled at people like Bobby Lopez, who did ""Avenue Q,"" and Michael John LaChiusa and Jason Robert Brown.
These are really top names in their industry.
(Soundbite of ""Wonder Pets"" Theme Song)
(Singing) Wonder Pets.
Wonder Pets.
We're on our way to help a baby penguin and save the day.
(As Ming-Ming Duckling) (Singing) We're not too big.
(As Turtle Tuck) And we're not too tough.
(Singing) But when we work together we've got the right stuff.
Go, Wonder Pets.
Yehey(ph).
Each episode of the ""Wonder Pets"" contains two 11-minute mini-operettas, with wall-to-wall music.
Regardless of who the composer is, every show contains certain recurring musical themes.
Those themes were written by Larry Hochman, who orchestrated the Broadway hit ""Spamalot.
There is the…
(Singing) Linny, Tuck, and Ming-Ming, too.
And there is the ""Wonder Pets"" song, I call it…
(Singing) Wonder Pets.
Wonder Pets, we're on our way.
And the opening, the phone is ringing sequence…
(Singing) There's an animal in trouble.
There's an animal in trouble.
There's an animal in trouble somewhere.
(Soundbite of scene from ""Wonder Pets"")
(As Linny the Guinea Pig) (Singing) There's an animal in trouble.
(As Ming-Ming Duckling) (Singing) There's an animal in trouble.
(As Turtle Tuck) (Singing) There's an animal in trouble somewhere.

Bobby Lopez, the Tony Award-winning songwriter of ""Avenue Q,"" has written for both the ""Wonder Pets"" and ""Johnny and The Sprites."" He says working on these programs has allowed him to expand his musical palette and emulate composers from Cole Porter to Sergei Prokofiev.
My one Broadway credit, ""Avenue Q,"" is actually more musically simple than a lot of the things that I've done for children's TV, because it, itself, is a take-off on children's TV.
And that may be why I'm in this position to have done all this children's TV.
Lopez has composed four episodes of the ""Wonder Pets"" with his brother Billy, including a popular one called ""The Puppy.
MR.
LOPEZ: Which is all about a puppy that has to take wiz, to go the bathroom.

(As Linny the Guinea Pig) (Singing) Ducks do it.
Frogs do it.
